SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCE: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A. METHOD OF ORIENTATION TO THE PIONEER EXPERIENCE QUESTIONNAIRE

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who has lived in Saskatchewan will have exactly the same experiences as another.

Some of the questions here will not apply to your experience; others may prove impossible for you to answer so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use "I don't know" or "not applicable" if there is not sufficient space to answer the question.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who have lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled Pioneer Life: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat? is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing and churchwork
( ) Pioneer education and employment
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

21. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They were mostly afraid of the harsh climate.

22. Did you travel by yourself or with a family (father, mother, children)? We came as a family but father had been out west until 1894.

23. What means of transportation did you use? We used the Canadian Pacific Railway.

24. How many people were in your family? We had 6 people.

28. What was the most memorable experience? Meeting new people and making friends.

29. What was the best part of the journey? Seeing the beautiful scenery.

30. What was the worst part of the journey? The long train ride.

31. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? We stayed at a farm.

32. Where did you settle or take up land? We settled in the Alameda district.

33. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. We moved to the railroad town in 1891 until 1894.

34. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

My family were blacksmiths in Alberta until we moved here. Then we started the farm at Cochrane for 3 years. We opened up a blacksmith shop in the little village of alameda which ended as part of a store and 2 families.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home? Shortly 2 or 3 times a year.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? It was a place to settle especially because it had commerce and an opportunity to earn a living doing business and making a living.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled. Also names.

Our brothers farmed in Ontario and Alberta until 1910. Our mother farmed in Ontario and Alberta. Parents.

My other brother worked in Canada about 18 years to 1900. He was only about 18 when he left.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting relatives, etc.) How often how far?

Had a good time by town farm working from Edmonton to Nanton. Worked hard. It was difficult at first because we had a house to build and food to grow. We also needed a lot of lumber. We had a hard time getting food and supplies. However, it was a good experience. We learned a lot of things from our work.
